elements.content: Two porous coordination polymers, {[Co0.5(TBC)]·2DMF} n (1) and {[Co­(TBC)­Cl0.5(CH3OH)]·0.5Cl} n (2), were synthesized via the solvothermal reaction of cobalt­(II) salts and 3,5-bis­(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­benzenecarboxylic acid. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses exhibited that complex 1 contains rtl three-dimensional (3D) skeleton and one-dimensional channels with large apertures, while complex 2 displays a novel 2-nodal 3,6-linked 3D structure with a Schläfli sign of {4.82}2{46.89} and contains micropores. Meanwhile, compound 2 shows selective adsorption properties of anionic methyl orange in a water solution. The dye adsorption studies of 1 and 2 revealed that the porous character and charge properties of metal–organic frameworks are two important factors heavily influencing dye adsorption.
elements.clean_text: Two porous coordination polymers, {[Co0.5(TBC)]⋅2DMF} n  (1) and {[Co(TBC)Cl0.5(CH3OH)]⋅0.5Cl} n  (2), were synthesized via the solvothermal reaction of cobalt(II) salts and 3,5-bis(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)benzenecarboxylic acid. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses exhibited that complex 1 contains rtl three-dimensional (3D) skeleton and one-dimensional channels with large apertures, while complex 2 displays a novel 2-nodal 3,6-linked 3D structure with a Schläfli sign of {4.82}2{46.89} and contains micropores. Meanwhile, compound 2 shows selective adsorption properties of anionic methyl orange in a water solution. The dye adsorption studies of 1 and 2 revealed that the porous character and charge properties of metal-organic frameworks are two important factors heavily influencing dye adsorption.

elements.content: Using multifunctional ligand 3,5-bis­(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­benzenecarboxylic acid, two new cobalt­(II) compounds have been isolated by changing the counteranions at nearly the same condition. 1 is a 3,6-connected net showing rtl topology, and 2 is also a 3,6-connected framework but with unprecedented dag topology. In addition, the cationic metal−organic framework 2 shows preferential adsorption of methyl orange from a water solution.
elements.clean_text: Using multifunctional ligand 3,5-bis(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)benzenecarboxylic acid, two new cobalt(II) compounds have been isolated by changing the counteranions at nearly the same condition. 1 is a 3,6-connected net showing rtl topology, and 2 is also a 3,6-connected framework but with unprecedented dag topology. In addition, the cationic metal-organic framework 2 shows preferential adsorption of methyl orange from a water solution.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with bulk pores as well as large/long channels have received tremendous attention recently for their outstanding capabilities in the areas of gas deposition and segregation, interfacial catalysis, chemical sensation, etc. So, studies on the design and self-assembly of MOFs were seriously focused on. As distinguished from activated carbon, molecular sieve, amorphous nickel, and such kinds of inorganic porous substances, the frame structure, pore shape, and size, as well as functionalities, of MOFs could be modulated from the molecular level. For example, MOFs are able to be designed and tuned through the rationalization of organolinkers and metal units. However, the final structures of the synthesized coordination polymers heavily depend on the reactant activation, amount, and related ratios. Furthermore, synthesis conditions, i.e., solvents properties, heating programs and temperature holding point, pH control, counteranions, etc., will also take deep influence on the final structures and properties. Comparably, the appropriate selection of organic linkers with a special geometry has been considered as a convenient way to fabricate novel and desirable MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with bulk pores as well as large/long channels have received tremendous attention recently for their outstanding capabilities in the areas of gas deposition and segregation, interfacial catalysis, chemical sensation, etc. So, studies on the design and self-assembly of MOFs were seriously focused on. As distinguished from activated carbon, molecular sieve, amorphous nickel, and such kinds of inorganic porous substances, the frame structure, pore shape, and size, as well as functionalities, of MOFs could be modulated from the molecular level. For example, MOFs are able to be designed and tuned through the rationalization of organolinkers and metal units. However, the final structures of the synthesized coordination polymers heavily depend on the reactant activation, amount, and related ratios. Furthermore, synthesis conditions, i.e., solvents properties, heating programs and temperature holding point, pH control, counteranions, etc., will also take deep influence on the final structures and properties. Comparably, the appropriate selection of organic linkers with a special geometry has been considered as a convenient way to fabricate novel and desirable MOFs.

elements.content: Environmental pollution involving organic pollutants has become more and more serious in recent years worldwide because of rapidly increasing population and undercontrolled industrial development. Among them, organic dyes, as very important industry additives, are now widely used in plastics, cosmetics, textiles, paper, and pharmaceuticals industries. However, organic dyes are also typical kinds of organic pollutants, lead to severe air, water, and soil contamination, result in disastrous environmental pollution, and are a health hazard. Therefore, the identification and selective adsorption of organic dyes has become very crucial to human health and environmental protection. Because of their tunable pore sizes, MOFs provide a suitable environment for interfacial interaction between the adsorbed molecules and pore substrate. Usually, the guest molecules were embedded in the holes of the MOFs through weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding, electrostatic, or π–π stacking, and also maybe through strong interactions via coordination with metal centers. Hence, in order to enhance the selectivity of dye adsorption, the pore dimensions and free volume of MOFs should be carefully designed and modulated during the assembly process, which should be the key point in producing a perfect MOF and is surely a very challenging task.
elements.clean_text: Environmental pollution involving organic pollutants has become more and more serious in recent years worldwide because of rapidly increasing population and undercontrolled industrial development. Among them, organic dyes, as very important industry additives, are now widely used in plastics, cosmetics, textiles, paper, and pharmaceuticals industries. However, organic dyes are also typical kinds of organic pollutants, lead to severe air, water, and soil contamination, result in disastrous environmental pollution, and are a health hazard. Therefore, the identification and selective adsorption of organic dyes has become very crucial to human health and environmental protection. Because of their tunable pore sizes, MOFs provide a suitable environment for interfacial interaction between the adsorbed molecules and pore substrate. Usually, the guest molecules were embedded in the holes of the MOFs through weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding, electrostatic, or π-π stacking, and also maybe through strong interactions via coordination with metal centers. Hence, in order to enhance the selectivity of dye adsorption, the pore dimensions and free volume of MOFs should be carefully designed and modulated during the assembly process, which should be the key point in producing a perfect MOF and is surely a very challenging task.

elements.content: Recently, organic molecules containing triazole or carboxylate functional groups are two kinds of special ligands that are now widely applied in the construction of MOFs. On their basis, various MOFs with outstanding structural diversities, high stabilities, and excellent properties have been successively synthesized.
elements.clean_text: Recently, organic molecules containing triazole or carboxylate functional groups are two kinds of special ligands that are now widely applied in the construction of MOFs. On their basis, various MOFs with outstanding structural diversities, high stabilities, and excellent properties have been successively synthesized.

elements.content: For the purpose of increasing the coordination function and possible synergism of the two functional groups, a multifunctional ligand, 3,5-bis­(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­benzenecarboxylic acid (HTBC), as the triangular linker was selected in our study. Two new porous MOFs, namely, {[Co0.5(TBC)]·2DMF} n (1), and {[Co­(TBC)­Cl0.5(CH3OH)]·0.5Cl} n (2), were obtained with different counteranions at nearly the same condition (). MOF 1 is a 3,6-connected network processing rtl topology, and 2 is also a 3,6-connected framework structure but has unprecedented dag topology. Moreover, no obvious adsorption of organic dyes is observed for neutral MOF 1, while the cationic MOF 2 shows preferential adsorption of methyl orange (MO) from a water solution.
elements.clean_text: For the purpose of increasing the coordination function and possible synergism of the two functional groups, a multifunctional ligand, 3,5-bis(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)benzenecarboxylic acid (HTBC), as the triangular linker was selected in our study. Two new porous MOFs, namely, {[Co0.5(TBC)]⋅2DMF} n  (1), and {[Co(TBC)Cl0.5(CH3OH)]⋅0.5Cl} n  (2), were obtained with different counteranions at nearly the same condition (). MOF 1 is a 3,6-connected network processing rtl topology, and 2 is also a 3,6-connected framework structure but has unprecedented dag topology. Moreover, no obvious adsorption of organic dyes is observed for neutral MOF 1, while the cationic MOF 2 shows preferential adsorption of methyl orange (MO) from a water solution.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis Routes of Coordination Polymers 1 and 2

elements.content: Most of the reagents were obtained commercially and added directly without any special treatment, except that the solvent dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was used after being dried over a molecular sieve and distilled under pressure. 3,5-Bis­(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­benzenecarboxylic acid (HTBC) was synthesized according to the reported literature. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were characterized on a PerkinElmer elemental indicator. Thermal behavior was studied by a NETZSCH TG 209 instrument under a nitrogen protecting atmosphere, and the heating rate was controlled at 10 °C·min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction was applied on a D/Max-2500 X-ray detector using Cu Kα radiation. UV/vis adsorption spectra were checked on a UV-2600 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Substance Used and Physical Measurement

Most of the reagents were obtained commercially and added directly without any special treatment, except that the solvent dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was used after being dried over a molecular sieve and distilled under pressure. 3,5-Bis(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)benzenecarboxylic acid (HTBC) was synthesized according to the reported literature. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were characterized on a PerkinElmer elemental indicator. Thermal behavior was studied by a NETZSCH TG 209 instrument under a nitrogen protecting atmosphere, and the heating rate was controlled at 10 °C⋅min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction was applied on a D/Max-2500 X-ray detector using Cu Kα radiation. UV/vis adsorption spectra were checked on a UV-2600 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A solution of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 6 mL of methanol (CH3OH)/N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 1:2, v/v) was added to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) and heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.2 °C·h–1. Orange-yellow crystalline products 1 (18.1 mg) were obtained (yield 42% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C17H21Co0.5N8O4 (430.88): C, 47.38, ;H, 4.91; N, 26.01. Found: C, 47.59; H, 5.06; N, 26.12.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Co0.5(TBC)]⋅2DMF} n  (1)

A solution of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 6 mL of methanol (CH3OH)/N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 1:2, v/v) was added to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) and heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.2 °C⋅h-1. Orange-yellow crystalline products 1 (18.1 mg) were obtained (yield 42% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C17H21Co0.5N8O4 (430.88): C, 47.38, ;H, 4.91; N, 26.01. Found: C, 47.59; H, 5.06; N, 26.12.

elements.content: A mixture of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a solution of 6 mL of CH3OH/DMF (1:2, v/v) in a beaker and stirred for 20 min. After the addition of 4 drops of HCl­(aq) (3 M), the mixture was transferred to a stainless vessel (15 mL) of Teflon linkage, heated to 100 °C, and kept there for 72 h. After that, the obtained autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a speed of 1.2 °C·h–1. Pink crystallized products 2 (19.8 mg) were finally produced (yield 52% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C12H11ClCoN6O3 (381.65): C, 37.76; H, 2.90; N, 22.03. Found: C, 37.43; H, 2.56; N, 21.98.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Co(TBC)Cl0.5(CH3OH)]⋅0.5Cl} n  (2)

A mixture of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a solution of 6 mL of CH3OH/DMF (1:2, v/v) in a beaker and stirred for 20 min. After the addition of 4 drops of HCl(aq) (3 M), the mixture was transferred to a stainless vessel (15 mL) of Teflon linkage, heated to 100 °C, and kept there for 72 h. After that, the obtained autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a speed of 1.2 °C⋅h-1. Pink crystallized products 2 (19.8 mg) were finally produced (yield 52% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C12H11ClCoN6O3 (381.65): C, 37.76; H, 2.90; N, 22.03. Found: C, 37.43; H, 2.56; N, 21.98.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicated that complex 1 is affiliated with the monoclinic system and P21/n space group (Table S1). It was revealed that the repeated unit in complex 1 is composed of half of a Co2+ ion, one TBC– ligand, and two free DMF molecules. As depicted in a, Co1 is hexacoordinated with a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by two oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two TBC– ligands and four nitrogen atoms from another four different TBC– ligands. The lengths of both the Co–N and Co–O bonds are found in the ordinary range. In the TBC– ligand, the two triazolyl rings and the carboxylate group are not coplanar with the inner phenyl ring, which is critical to the construction of three-dimensional (3D) MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Descriptions

Crystal Structure of 1 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicated that complex 1 is affiliated with the monoclinic system and P21/n space group (Table S1). It was revealed that the repeated unit in complex 1 is composed of half of a Co2+ ion, one TBC- ligand, and two free DMF molecules. As depicted in a, Co1 is hexacoordinated with a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by two oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two TBC- ligands and four nitrogen atoms from another four different TBC- ligands. The lengths of both the Co-N and Co-O bonds are found in the ordinary range. In the TBC- ligand, the two triazolyl rings and the carboxylate group are not coplanar with the inner phenyl ring, which is critical to the construction of three-dimensional (3D) MOFs.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of cobalt­(II) ions in 1. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Symmetry operator: #1 = 1.5 – x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; #2 = 0.5 + x, 1.5 – y, −0.5 + z; #3 = −0.5 + x, 1.5 – y, −0.5 + z; #4 = 2.5 – x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; #5 = 2 – x, 1 – y, −z. (b) Pore size of the 1D channels in 1. (c) 3D framework of 1 viewed along the a direction. (d) 3D porous MOFs of 1. (e) 3D topological structure of 1 viewed along the b direction. Color codes: green codes, 3-connected TBC–-ligand; purple codes, 6-connected Co2+ ions.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of cobalt(II) ions in 1. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Symmetry operator: #1 = 1.5 - x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; #2 = 0.5 + x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z; #3 = -0.5 + x, 1.5 - y, -0.5 + z; #4 = 2.5 - x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; #5 = 2 - x, 1 - y, -z. (b) Pore size of the 1D channels in 1. (c) 3D framework of 1 viewed along the a direction. (d) 3D porous MOFs of 1. (e) 3D topological structure of 1 viewed along the b direction. Color codes: green codes, 3-connected TBC--ligand; purple codes, 6-connected Co2+ ions.

elements.content: Each TBC– ligand exhibits a triangle linker, while each cobalt­(II) center, coordinated with six TBC– linkers, gives a 3D framework that contains one-dimensional (1D) oblique square micropore channels with a diameter of approximately 1.02 nm (corresponding to van der Waals radii; b–d). As concluded from the topological point, Co2+ serves as a 6-connected node and the TBC– ligand serves as a 3-connected node. The MOFs could be narrated as a 2-nodal 3,6-connected 3D rtl-type framework structure with a Schläfli symbol of {4.62}2{42.610.83}, as found in d. Calculated using PLATON, the ratio of the accessible porous volume (utilizable) in every unit cell is 55.1%.
elements.clean_text: Each TBC- ligand exhibits a triangle linker, while each cobalt(II) center, coordinated with six TBC- linkers, gives a 3D framework that contains one-dimensional (1D) oblique square micropore channels with a diameter of approximately 1.02 nm (corresponding to van der Waals radii; b-d). As concluded from the topological point, Co2+ serves as a 6-connected node and the TBC- ligand serves as a 3-connected node. The MOFs could be narrated as a 2-nodal 3,6-connected 3D rtl-type framework structure with a Schläfli symbol of {4.62}2{42.610.83}, as found in d. Calculated using PLATON, the ratio of the accessible porous volume (utilizable) in every unit cell is 55.1%.

elements.content: X-ray structural study indicates that compound 2 belongs to the tetragonal system and space group P42/mnm (Table S1), and the asymmetric unit comprises half of a Co2+ cation, half of a TBC– ligand, one-fourth of a Cl– anion, and a half-coordinated CH3OH as well as counteranions residing in the cationic framework. As shown in , each CoII ion is coordinated by two triazole N atoms from two TBC– ligands and two carboxylate O atoms from another two TBC– ligands, as well as by one methanol O atom and one Cl ion in the form of a distorted octahedron configuration. The lengths of the Co–O bonds are in the range of 2.057(3)–2.136(6) Å, while the Co–N and Co–Cl bond lengths are 2.135(5) and 2.434(2) Å, respectively. Two hexacoordinated Co2+ ions are bridged by one Cl ion and two μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate groups from two TBC– ligands, to form a binuclear paddle wheel with a Co–Co distance of 3.649(5) Å (a). The binuclear coordination units are further bridged by six triangle linkers TBC– to form the 3D framework (b). The framework topology was analyzed by the freely available computer program TOPOS to obtain a simplified framework. If every binuclear unit Co2 is defined as a 6-connected node and TBC– linkers are treated as 3-connected nodes that link the Co2 binuclear units, the 3D framework then could be expressed as a 3,6-connected dag structure with a short (Schläfli) vertex symbol of {4.82}2{46.89} (d). This topology is uncommon and has not been reported in previous studies. Moreover, 1D irregular-shaped microporous channels exist along the a direction, and the ratio of accessible pore volume in one unit cell is 47.9%, calculated by PLATON. Further, the accessible volume was occupied by Cl– ions.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 2 

X-ray structural study indicates that compound 2 belongs to the tetragonal system and space group P42/mnm (Table S1), and the asymmetric unit comprises half of a Co2+ cation, half of a TBC- ligand, one-fourth of a Cl- anion, and a half-coordinated CH3OH as well as counteranions residing in the cationic framework. As shown in , each CoII ion is coordinated by two triazole N atoms from two TBC- ligands and two carboxylate O atoms from another two TBC- ligands, as well as by one methanol O atom and one Cl ion in the form of a distorted octahedron configuration. The lengths of the Co-O bonds are in the range of 2.057(3)-2.136(6) Å, while the Co-N and Co-Cl bond lengths are 2.135(5) and 2.434(2) Å, respectively. Two hexacoordinated Co2+ ions are bridged by one Cl ion and two μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate groups from two TBC- ligands, to form a binuclear paddle wheel with a Co-Co distance of 3.649(5) Å (a). The binuclear coordination units are further bridged by six triangle linkers TBC- to form the 3D framework (b). The framework topology was analyzed by the freely available computer program TOPOS to obtain a simplified framework. If every binuclear unit Co2 is defined as a 6-connected node and TBC- linkers are treated as 3-connected nodes that link the Co2 binuclear units, the 3D framework then could be expressed as a 3,6-connected dag structure with a short (Schläfli) vertex symbol of {4.82}2{46.89} (d). This topology is uncommon and has not been reported in previous studies. Moreover, 1D irregular-shaped microporous channels exist along the a direction, and the ratio of accessible pore volume in one unit cell is 47.9%, calculated by PLATON. Further, the accessible volume was occupied by Cl- ions.

elements.content: (a) Dinuclear CoII coordination unit in 2. (b) 3D framework of 2 viewed along the a direction. (c) 3D porous MOFs of 2. (d) dag topological structure of 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Dinuclear CoII coordination unit in 2. (b) 3D framework of 2 viewed along the a direction. (c) 3D porous MOFs of 2. (d) dag topological structure of 2.

elements.content: Organic dyes were largely used in printing, paper, textile, food, and pharmacy industries and are the very common organic pollutants. Unfortunately, organic dyes could induce serious environmental problems even at most lower concentrations. MOFs of special pore diameter and accessible space possess a highly efficient ability for the selective adsorption and trapping of most of organic dyes. Theoretically, ionic MOFs may take advantage of the selective adsorption of cationic or anionic dyes, and neutral MOFs may be better for the selective adsorption of neutral dyes because of the interaction of host–guest electrostatic and/or guest–guest exchange. Considering the neutral framework of 1 and the charge skeleton of complex 2, two kinds of anionic organic dyes, congo red (CR–) and MO–, and three kinds of cationic dyes, methylene blue (MB+), janus green B (JGB+), and rhodamine B (RB+), as well as one kind of neutral dye, dimethyl yellow (DY; ), were used as diagnostic agents to evaluate and testify to the adsorption capacity of the porous frameworks 1 and 2. Because complex 1 has a neutral framework, it may have good selective adsorption for neutral dye DY. Owing to the poor solubility of DY in aqueous solution, the dye adsorption test was carried out in a methanol solution. Complex 1 was checked for uptake of MO–, DY, MB+, and JGB+ by soaking identical amounts (5 mg) of 1 in methanol solutions containing the above four kinds of organic dyes (5 mL, 2 × 10–5 M) at room temperature. Also, their concentrations were online measured and adjusted by UV/vis spectroscopy according to the function time. As described in a–d, the concentrations of organic dyes MO–, DY, MB+, and JGB+ decrease slowly with time, and it should be included that these dyes cannot be adsorbed efficiently by 1. Considering the ionic framework characteristics of complex 2, four kinds of ionic organic dyes, MO–, CR–, MB+, and RB+, were chosen to assess the adsorption capacity of 2. Unlike complex 1, the adsorption test for 2 was carried out in an aqueous solution of the dyes, which is more convenient for practical applications. Crystals of 2 (5 mg) were added and dissolved in the respective aqueous solutions (5 mL, 2 × 10–5 M). Changes in the color of the MO– solution could be easily observed as time passed, and the solution finally became almost lucid after 24 h of absorption (a). On the basis of the UV/vis spectroscopy testing results (), the sequence of the adsorption rate was found to be MO– > CR– > MB+ > RB+. After 24 h of adsorption, the MO– concentration remained only 17.3%, as checked by UV/vis absorption spectroscopy. Also, it was concluded that 2 has a strong capability and high efficiency for adsorption of MO–. After 24 h of adsorption under the same testing conditions, the concentrations of CR–, MB+, and RB+ still remained 56.3%, 83.7% and 94.3%, respectively. On the basis of pole diameter analyses, small MO– molecules are able to easily transpass the pore in 2. However, the transportation could be strongly retarded by large distortion of CR– of the pore. So, complex 2 is suggested to have an advantage for the adsorbing anionic dyes, and the molecular size has the most important influence on dye adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Selective Adsorption and Release of Dyes

Organic dyes were largely used in printing, paper, textile, food, and pharmacy industries and are the very common organic pollutants. Unfortunately, organic dyes could induce serious environmental problems even at most lower concentrations. MOFs of special pore diameter and accessible space possess a highly efficient ability for the selective adsorption and trapping of most of organic dyes. Theoretically, ionic MOFs may take advantage of the selective adsorption of cationic or anionic dyes, and neutral MOFs may be better for the selective adsorption of neutral dyes because of the interaction of host-guest electrostatic and/or guest-guest exchange. Considering the neutral framework of 1 and the charge skeleton of complex 2, two kinds of anionic organic dyes, congo red (CR-) and MO-, and three kinds of cationic dyes, methylene blue (MB+), janus green B (JGB+), and rhodamine B (RB+), as well as one kind of neutral dye, dimethyl yellow (DY; ), were used as diagnostic agents to evaluate and testify to the adsorption capacity of the porous frameworks 1 and 2. Because complex 1 has a neutral framework, it may have good selective adsorption for neutral dye DY. Owing to the poor solubility of DY in aqueous solution, the dye adsorption test was carried out in a methanol solution. Complex 1 was checked for uptake of MO-, DY, MB+, and JGB+ by soaking identical amounts (5 mg) of 1 in methanol solutions containing the above four kinds of organic dyes (5 mL, 2 × 10-5 M) at room temperature. Also, their concentrations were online measured and adjusted by UV/vis spectroscopy according to the function time. As described in a-d, the concentrations of organic dyes MO-, DY, MB+, and JGB+ decrease slowly with time, and it should be included that these dyes cannot be adsorbed efficiently by 1. Considering the ionic framework characteristics of complex 2, four kinds of ionic organic dyes, MO-, CR-, MB+, and RB+, were chosen to assess the adsorption capacity of 2. Unlike complex 1, the adsorption test for 2 was carried out in an aqueous solution of the dyes, which is more convenient for practical applications. Crystals of 2 (5 mg) were added and dissolved in the respective aqueous solutions (5 mL, 2 × 10-5 M). Changes in the color of the MO- solution could be easily observed as time passed, and the solution finally became almost lucid after 24 h of absorption (a). On the basis of the UV/vis spectroscopy testing results (), the sequence of the adsorption rate was found to be MO- > CR- > MB+ > RB+. After 24 h of adsorption, the MO- concentration remained only 17.3%, as checked by UV/vis absorption spectroscopy. Also, it was concluded that 2 has a strong capability and high efficiency for adsorption of MO-. After 24 h of adsorption under the same testing conditions, the concentrations of CR-, MB+, and RB+ still remained 56.3%, 83.7% and 94.3%, respectively. On the basis of pole diameter analyses, small MO- molecules are able to easily transpass the pore in 2. However, the transportation could be strongly retarded by large distortion of CR- of the pore. So, complex 2 is suggested to have an advantage for the adsorbing anionic dyes, and the molecular size has the most important influence on dye adsorption.

elements.content: Dye treatment by selective adsorption using MOFs is now at the leading edge of technology and is full of experimental challenges. For further study, MO– and MB+ were selected for a detailed comparison experiment () concerning their similarity size but differing charge. Crystals 2 (5 mg) were added into the aqueous solution of equimolar concentrations of MB+ and MO– (2 × 10–5 M) for the adsorption, and the process was supervised by UV/vis spectroscopy. Testing results indicate that just MO could be incorporated into the caves of MOF 2 (). Because of the similarity in the molecular diameter between MO– and MB+, it could be deduced that the selective trap of MO– is due to the charge-matching effect of the MOF, which means that Cl– ions could be exchanged by the anionic dye. Further studies by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S2) revealed that the crystal structure of complex 2 remained unchanged before and after the adsorption process.
elements.clean_text: Dye treatment by selective adsorption using MOFs is now at the leading edge of technology and is full of experimental challenges. For further study, MO- and MB+ were selected for a detailed comparison experiment () concerning their similarity size but differing charge. Crystals 2 (5 mg) were added into the aqueous solution of equimolar concentrations of MB+ and MO- (2 × 10-5 M) for the adsorption, and the process was supervised by UV/vis spectroscopy. Testing results indicate that just MO could be incorporated into the caves of MOF 2 (). Because of the similarity in the molecular diameter between MO- and MB+, it could be deduced that the selective trap of MO- is due to the charge-matching effect of the MOF, which means that Cl- ions could be exchanged by the anionic dye. Further studies by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S2) revealed that the crystal structure of complex 2 remained unchanged before and after the adsorption process.

elements.content: Selective adsorption capability of different dye (MO– + MB+) aqueous solutions in the presence of 2 with time.
elements.clean_text: 5  Selective adsorption capability of different dye (MO- + MB+) aqueous solutions in the presence of 2 with time.

elements.content: Especially, the reversibility and stability of the pore frameworks after dye adsorption and desorption are extremely important to practical applications. Herein, the dye-release experiments were carried out in purified water and a saturated NaCl aqueous solution. The results exhibit that it is difficult to release MO– effectively from MO–@2 in pure water ( and S4), while under NaCl acting as a trigger, MO– can be gradually released from the MO–@2 ( and S5), which further confirms that the adsorption of MO– is an ion-exchange mechanism.
elements.clean_text: Especially, the reversibility and stability of the pore frameworks after dye adsorption and desorption are extremely important to practical applications. Herein, the dye-release experiments were carried out in purified water and a saturated NaCl aqueous solution. The results exhibit that it is difficult to release MO- effectively from MO-@2 in pure water ( and S4), while under NaCl acting as a trigger, MO- can be gradually released from the MO-@2 ( and S5), which further confirms that the adsorption of MO- is an ion-exchange mechanism.

elements.content: Release rate comparison of MO– from MO–@2 in pure aqueous solution and a NaCl saturated aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: 6  Release rate comparison of MO- from MO-@2 in pure aqueous solution and a NaCl saturated aqueous solution.

elements.content: In summary, two porous MOFs based on a bifunctional ligand HTBC were successfully constructed. Complex 1 exhibits a rtl 3D framework and contains 1D nanoporous channels, while complex 2 displays an unprecedented 2-nodal 3,6-connected dag structure with micropores. Compared with 1, complex 2 exhibits much better selective adsorption properties to MO– than the adsorption of other dyes in an aqueous solution. The excellent selective adsorption and desorption properties, as well as its properties of ease of preparation and convenient manipulation, make it highly valuable for potential applications in dye-related environmental pollution.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two porous MOFs based on a bifunctional ligand HTBC were successfully constructed. Complex 1 exhibits a rtl 3D framework and contains 1D nanoporous channels, while complex 2 displays an unprecedented 2-nodal 3,6-connected dag structure with micropores. Compared with 1, complex 2 exhibits much better selective adsorption properties to MO- than the adsorption of other dyes in an aqueous solution. The excellent selective adsorption and desorption properties, as well as its properties of ease of preparation and convenient manipulation, make it highly valuable for potential applications in dye-related environmental pollution.

cln_elements.content:
A solution of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 6 mL of methanol (CH3OH)/N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 1:2, v/v) was added to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) and heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.2 °C·h–1. Orange-yellow crystalline products 1 (18.1 mg) were obtained (yield 42% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C17H21Co0.5N8O4 (430.88): C, 47.38, ;H, 4.91; N, 26.01. Found: C, 47.59; H, 5.06; N, 26.12.

Synthesis of {[Co­(TBC)­Cl<sub>0.5</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)]·0.5Cl}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a solution of 6 mL of CH3OH/DMF (1:2, v/v) in a beaker and stirred for 20 min. After the addition of 4 drops of HCl­(aq) (3 M), the mixture was transferred to a stainless vessel (15 mL) of Teflon linkage, heated to 100 °C, and kept there for 72 h. After that, the obtained autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a speed of 1.2 °C·h–1. Pink crystallized products 2 (19.8 mg) were finally produced (yield 52% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C12H11ClCoN6O3 (381.65): C, 37.76; H, 2.90; N, 22.03. Found: C, 37.43; H, 2.56; N, 21.98.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Co0.5(TBC)]⋅2DMF} n  (1)

A solution of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 6 mL of methanol (CH3OH)/N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 1:2, v/v) was added to a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) and heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.2 °C⋅h-1. Orange-yellow crystalline products 1 (18.1 mg) were obtained (yield 42% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C17H21Co0.5N8O4 (430.88): C, 47.38, ;H, 4.91; N, 26.01. Found: C, 47.59; H, 5.06; N, 26.12.

Synthesis of {[Co(TBC)Cl0.5(CH3OH)]⋅0.5Cl} n  (2)

A mixture of HTBC (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a solution of 6 mL of CH3OH/DMF (1:2, v/v) in a beaker and stirred for 20 min. After the addition of 4 drops of HCl(aq) (3 M), the mixture was transferred to a stainless vessel (15 mL) of Teflon linkage, heated to 100 °C, and kept there for 72 h. After that, the obtained autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a speed of 1.2 °C⋅h-1. Pink crystallized products 2 (19.8 mg) were finally produced (yield 52% based on cobalt). Anal. Calcd for C12H11ClCoN6O3 (381.65): C, 37.76; H, 2.90; N, 22.03. Found: C, 37.43; H, 2.56; N, 21.98.

cln_elements.content: Each TBC– ligand exhibits a triangle linker, while each cobalt­(II) center, coordinated with six TBC– linkers, gives a 3D framework that contains one-dimensional (1D) oblique square micropore channels with a diameter of approximately 1.02 nm (corresponding to van der Waals radii; b–d). As concluded from the topological point, Co2+ serves as a 6-connected node and the TBC– ligand serves as a 3-connected node. The MOFs could be narrated as a 2-nodal 3,6-connected 3D rtl-type framework structure with a Schläfli symbol of {4.62}2{42.610.83}, as found in d. Calculated using PLATON, the ratio of the accessible porous volume (utilizable) in every unit cell is 55.1%.
cln_elements.clean_text: Each TBC- ligand exhibits a triangle linker, while each cobalt(II) center, coordinated with six TBC- linkers, gives a 3D framework that contains one-dimensional (1D) oblique square micropore channels with a diameter of approximately 1.02 nm (corresponding to van der Waals radii; b-d). As concluded from the topological point, Co2+ serves as a 6-connected node and the TBC- ligand serves as a 3-connected node. The MOFs could be narrated as a 2-nodal 3,6-connected 3D rtl-type framework structure with a Schläfli symbol of {4.62}2{42.610.83}, as found in d. Calculated using PLATON, the ratio of the accessible porous volume (utilizable) in every unit cell is 55.1%.

metadata.title:
Two 3D Cobalt(II) Metal–Organic Frameworks
with Micropores for Selective
